The cellular changes that are most likely to be occurring within his myocardium after suffering a cardiac arrest and resuscitation efforts are (A) apoptosis and (B) free radical injury. 

Apoptosis, also known as programmed cell death, is a normal process that occurs in the heart and is essential for maintaining heart function. During a cardiac arrest, the heart停止跳动, and cells begin to die, leading to the formation of apoptosis. Resuscitation efforts can potentially cause further damage to the heart muscle, leading to more apoptosis.

Free radical injury occurs when the body produces excess reactive oxygen species (ROS) during a cardiac arrest, which can cause damage to the heart muscle. Resuscitation efforts can also cause further damage to the heart muscle, leading to more free radical injury.

Heterophagocytosis is a process in which a cell eats another cell, which is not related to the cellular changes that occur within the myocardium during a cardiac arrest.

Squamous metaplasia is a change in the normal structure of cells, which is not related to the cellular changes that occur within the myocardium during a cardiac arrest.
